repnme.cdata!:
India - Uttar Pradesh and Uttaranchal
            Forestry Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that programs
            involving complex institutional change need assured long
            term support or simpler design. The Project Appraisal
            Document (PAD) rightly recognized that complex process
            change was required to address state and national
            development priorities in the sector, which needed time. A
            well designed communication strategy in the project could
            have vastly improved the impact of the participatory
            management activities, avoided controversy over
            modifications of rules for Van Panchayats and Joint Forest
            Management (JFM). In view of the significance and importance
            of Van Panchayats in the hills, the PAD rightly acknowledged
            the need to strengthen these institutions as distinct from
            JFM. However, the importance of this was not followed
            through by including specific activities and clearly
            adopting a separate approach from that of JFM in the
            project. Monitoring, evaluation and management information
            systems need to be consistent with technical capacity. The
            Forest Management Information (FMIS) was overambitious given
            the existing (low) level of technical expertise in the FD
            and awareness amongst senior decision makers of its
            benefits. A more appropriate approach could have included,
            building computer and data management skills through
            training initially, which would have underpinned more
            meaningful interaction between users and developers of systems.

5081312.trustfund:
TF028118-BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY WORKSHOP,TF022765-WATER RESOURCES/INSTITUTIONS SPECIALIST,TF022586-PHRD-FOREST SECTOR
            DEVEL.-KERALA & UTTAR,TF033906-INDIA - AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY
5081312.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Trade and integration,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objective of the Uttar
            Pradesh Forestry Project is to assist with the
            implementation of the Government of Uttar Pradesh (GOUP)
            strategy for development of the forestry sector.  More
            specifically the development objectives are to: i) improve
            public sector management; ii) increase both forest cover and
            productivity; and iii) conserve biodiversity.  The four
            project components are: 1) Institutional development
            component.  2) The forest development component will finance
            interventions in forest resource development, including: a)
            natural forest management; b) plantation development; and c)
            farm, community, and urban forestry.  3) The research and
            technology component will develop a more effective research
            organization working to prioritize research programs.  4)
            Biodiversity conservation component.
